questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the medical methods of termination of pregnancy is correct

options.label: A
options.text: It can be done only upto 72 days from LMP

options.label: B
options.text: There is no need for removal of copper T before initiating the management

options.label: C
options.text: Only a RMP registered for MTP can perform

questions.correct_answer: C. Only a RMP registered for MTP can perform
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only a RMP registered for MTP can perform Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 (Act No. 34 of 1971) An Act to provide for the termination of certain pregnancies by registered medical practitioners and for matters connected therewith or incidental thereto When Pregnancies may be terminated by registered medical practitioners- 1. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Indian Penal Code (45 of 1860), a registered medical practitioner shall not-be guilty of any offence under that Code or under any other law for the time being in· force, if any pregnancy is terminated by him in accordance with the provisions of this Act. 2. Subject to the provisions of sub-section (4), a pregnancy may be terminated by a registered medical practitioner, - Where the length of the pregnancy does not exceed twelve weeks if such medical practitioner is (b) where the length of the pregnancy exceeds twelve weeks but does not exceed twenty weeks, if not less than two registered medical practitioners are. The continuance of the pregnancy would involve a risk to the life of the pregnant woman or of grave injury physical or mental health; or There is a substantial risk that if the child were born, it would suffer from such physical or mental abnormalities as to be seriously handicapped. 3. In determining whether the continuance of pregnancy would involve such risk of injury to the health as is mentioned in sub-section (2), account may be taken of the pregnant woman's actual or reasonable foreseeable environment. (a) No pregnancy of a woman, who has not attained the age of eighteen years, or, who, having attained the age of eighteen years, is a lunatic, shall be terminated except with the consent in writing of her guardian. (b) Same as otherwise provided in Cl.(a), no pregnancy shall be terminated except with the consent of the pregnant woman. 1. Place where pregnancy may be terminated. - No termination of pregnancy shall be made in accordance with this Act at any place other than, - (a) A hospital established or maintained by Government, or (b) A place for the time being approved for the purpose of this Act by Government.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about partograph is false

options.label: A
options.text: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation

options.label: B
options.text: Action line starts 4 hrs after the alert line

options.label: C
options.text: Each of the small box represents 1 hr

options.label: D
options.text: In case of partograph crossing the alert line, patient has to be referred to FRU

questions.correct_answer: C. Each of the small box represents 1 hr
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Each of the small box represents 1 hr The partograph is a graphical presentation of the progress of labour, and of fetal and maternal condition during labour. In the section for cervical dilatation and fetal head descent, there are two diagonal lines labelled Alert and Action. The Alert line starts at 4 cm of cervical dilatation and it travels diagonally upwards to the point of expected full dilatation (10 cm) at the rate of 1 cm per hour. The Action line is parallel to the Alert line, and 4 hours to the right of the Alert line. These two lines are designed to warn you to take action quickly if the labour is not progressing normally. You should refer the woman to a health centre or hospital if the marks recording cervical dilatation cross over the Alert line, i.e. indicating that cervical dilation is proceeding too slowly. (The Action line is for making decisions at health- facility level.)

questions.text: In the first trimester screening for Down syndrome which of the following test is to be done
Which of the following is correct regarding the attachment of the given muscle (external oblique)

options.label: A
options.text: I- linea semilunaris, II- Linea alba, III- inguinal ligament, IV- inner lip of iliac crest

options.label: B
options.text: I- Linea alba, II- Arcuate ligament, III- lacunar ligament, IV- outer lip of iliac crest

options.label: C
options.text: I- Linea alba, II- Linea semilunaris, III- inguinal ligament, IV- Inner lip of iliac crest

options.label: D
options.text: I- Linea alba, II- Linea semilunaris, III- Inguinal ligament, IV- outer lip of iliac crest

questions.correct_answer: D. I- Linea alba, II- Linea semilunaris, III- Inguinal ligament, IV- outer lip of iliac crest
questions.explanation:
Solution:

I- Linea alba, II- Linea semilunaris, III- Inguinal ligament, IV- outer lip of iliac crest External oblique muscle Origin The external oblique muscle arises from eight fleshy slips from the outer surfaces (the middle of the shaft) of lower eight ribs. Insertion 1. The posterior- most fibres pass vertically downward to be inserted on to the outer lip of the anterior two-third of the iliac crest. The posterior border of muscle is thus free. 2. The remaining fibres pass downward, forward and medially to end in a broad aponeurosis, which is inserted into the linea alba extending from the xiphoid process to the pubic symphysis. The upper border of the aponeurosis is free and overlapped by the fibres of pectoralis major muscle. The lower border of the aponeurosis is free and jumps from anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle bridging across the muscles, nerves, and vessels that enter the thigh from the abdomen The free lower border of the aponeurosis is thickened and rolled inward on itself to form the inguinal ligament

questions.text: Length of suture material required for midline laparotomy incision closure is

options.label: D
options.text: Equal to the length of wound

questions.correct_answer: A. 4 times the length of wound
questions.explanation:
Solution:

4 times the length of wound A common problem with many of the studies is the comparison of different suture techniques using different suture materials, Nonetheless, the large number of published reports makes available some conclusions: continuous suture technique is as reliable as interrupted technique; late hernias might be more common with quickly absorbed Vicryl or Dexon compared to slowly absorbed Maxon or PDS or nonabsorbable sutures; and late wound pain and sinus formation is more common with nonabsorbable sutures. Chromic (and therefore, plain) catgut has been found to be unacceptable because of its early loss of tensile strength. Taking deep bites of tissue is important and for continuous closure, a suture length to wound length ratio of at least 4:1.is recommended. This is easily done when closing the abdominal wall by placing sutures 2 cm from the fascial wound edge and 2 em apart, which will result in a ratio of 4.2:1 results of some of the more recent randomized studies follow.

questions.text: A primigravida at 38wks of gestation presented with pain. abdomen. On examination there was mild contraction present, cervix was 2 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Which of the, following-is the next line of management
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Observation Bishop score A PV exam scoring system to determine if labour is likely to commence spontaneously of induction will be required. Total < 5 = labour unlikely to start without ripening the cervix Total ≥ 7 = labour should commence easily "Since the patient appears to be in early stages of latent phase of labour. Then in this case observation is the most probable answer"

questions.text: WHO recommended Oral Dose of misoprostol for prevention of post-partum hemorrhageis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

600 mcg Traditionally, postpartum hemorrhage has been defined as the loss of 500 mL of blood or more after completion of the third stage of labor WHO Recommendations for the prevention of PPH: 1. The use of uterotonic for the prevention of PPH during the third stage of labour is recommended for all births. 2. Oxytocin (10 IU, IV /IM) is the recommended uterotonic drug for the prevention of PPH. 3. In settings where oxytocin is unavailable, the use of other injectable uterotonic (if appropriate ergometrine/methyl ergometrine or the fixed drug combination of oxytocin and ergometrine) or oral misoprostol (600 µg) is recommended. 4. In settings where skilled birth attendants are not present and oxytocin is unavailable, the administration of misoprostol (600 µg PO} by community health, care workers and lay health workers is recommended for the prevention of PPH.

questions.text: A 35 years old female presented with an adnexal mass. CA125 was slightly raised, CA199 was normal and LDH was elevated. Tumor was resected and the gross and microscopic image were as given below. What the most likely diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dysgerminoma Dysgerminoma may occur in childhood, but 75 percent occur in second and third decades. Most of these tumors have no endocrine function. A few produce elevated levels of chorionic gonadotropin and may have Syncytio-trophoblastic giant cells on histological examination. Dysgerminoma (In above image) shows polyhedral tumor cells with round nuclei and adjacent inflammation. Useful tumor markers for Dysgerminoma: Beta-hCG AFP LDH Inhibin A and B Cancer antigen 125 (CA-125)

questions.text: As per WHO guidelines for screening of Ca cervix, which of the following statement is false

options.label: A
options.text: If HPV test is negative next screening done after 5yrs

options.label: B
options.text: Screening is more intense and focused for age 30-49 then for total no. of screening done till age 60

options.label: C
options.text: Visualization is more reliable in 65 years’ age as transformation zone is fixed

options.label: D
options.text: If one PAP is negative call the women for screening in 3-5yrs

questions.correct_answer: C. Visualization is more reliable in 65 years’ age as transformation zone is fixed
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Visualization is more reliable in 65 years’ age as transformation zone is fixed Recommended age to start screening for Cervical cancer is 30 years and older because of their higher risk of cervical cancer. However, the magnitude of the net benefit will differ among age groups and may extend to younger and older women depending on their baseline risk of CIN2+. Priority should be given to screening women aged 30-49 years, rather than maximizing the number of screening tests in a woman's lifetime. (Option B is true) Screening even once in a lifetime would be beneficial. Screening intervals may depend on financial, infrastructural, and other resources. The recommendations include strategies based on three screening tests: 1. HPV (cut-off level ≥ 1.0 pg/ml), 2. cytology (cut-off level ASCUS+, atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance), and 3. VIA (visual inspection with acetic acid) VIA is appropriate to use in women whose transformation zone is visible (typically in those younger than 50). This is because once menopause occurs, the transformation zone, where most precancerous lesions occur, frequently recedes into the endocervical canal and prevents it from being fully visible (Option C : False). Recommendation for follow up after screening: In women who test negative on VIA or cytology (Pap smear), the screening interval for repeat screening should be every three to five years (Option D: true). In women who test negative on an HPV test, rescreening should be done after a minimum interval of five years (Option A : True).

questions.text: An 18 girl presented with complains of primary amenorrhea. On examination breast was well developed, clitoris enlargement was present and had normal vagina. On USG gonads were found in inguinal canal. What is the most likely diagnosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Partial AIS Androgen Insensitivity Syndromes (AIS) The AISs are the most common forms of male DSD, The clinical spectrum of patients with AISs, all of whom have a 46,XY chromosomal complement, range from phenotypic females (incomplete AIS) to males with various forms of ambiguous genitalia and unde virilization (partial AIS) to phenotypically normal-appearing males with infertility. In addition to normal 46,XY chromosomes, the presence of testes and normal or elevated testosterone and LH levels are common to all such children Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS) It is an extreme form of failure of virilization, genetic males appear female at birth and are invariably reared accordingly. The external genitalia are female. The vagina ends blindly in a pouch, and the uterus is absent as a result of the normal production and effect of AMH by the testes. In about one third of patients, unilateral or bilateral fallopian tube remnants are found. The testes are usually intra-abdominal but may descend into the inguinal canal; they consist largely of seminiferous tubules. At puberty, there is normal development of breasts and the habitus is female, but menstruation does not occur and sexual hair is absent. Adult heights of these women are commensurate with those of normal males despite profound congenital deficiency of androgenic effects. Complete gonadal dysgenesis No gonadal development occurs Patients have a completely female phenotype due to the lack of any gonadal steroid production, but at pubertal age, breast development and menarche fail to occur. Eg 46, XY Swyer syndrome Partial Gonadal dysgenesis (PGD) In PGD in which a Y chromosome is present, there is incomplete testis de- termination and the external phenotype depends on the degree of testicular function. Genital ambiguity of variable degree ranging from almost female pheno- type to almost male phenotype in a patient carrying a male 46,XY karyotype. The most common karyotype seen in PGD is 45,Xj 46,XY, but 46,XY and other forms of mosaicism involving the Y chromosome also can be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about antenatal use of steroids for fetal lung maturation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses Current evidence supports the use of dexamethasone as the first choice of treatment: four 6-mg doses given 12- hourly. However, if dexamethasone is not available, betamethasone may be used: two 12- mg doses given 24- hourly
